title: 6 tech gadgets to help you get through your commute
text:
Flickr / Chris Marchant 
Most of us have to commute on a daily basis, and while the experience might not always be frustrating, it's hardly ever fun. 
The gadgets on this list will help keep you even-keeled on your way to and from work, whether they help block out the world, or actually make the process of commuting less annoying. 
They might not make that hour or two each day fly by, but they'll make sure that time won't crawl. 
Dealing with the sounds of the subway Amazon 
mixed with the idle chatter of other commuters isn't always fun in the early morning hours. 
Noise-cancelling headphones are a must-have, and Sony's H.ear headphones are among the best I've used. 
They're comfortable, sound great, and block out an incredible amount of noise. The only people on the train will be you and the musical artist or podcaster of your choice. 2. An external USB battery 
Amazon 
Few things are as frustrating as having your phone die on your commute home. All you want to do is kill time reading those articles you've been putting off all day, and now you're face to face with a blank screen. 
Anker's USB battery is compact enough to fit in a small backpack compartment or purse, and has enough juice to fully recharge most phones a couple of times over. 3. A handheld game console 
Amazon 
I tend to keep my gaming to home consoles these days, but I have friends who swear by playing games on their commute. 
The Nintendo 3DS has an exceptional library of games, and can still be slipped in and out of a backpack pocket or purse with ease. If you haven't owned a Nintendo handheld in a little while, you'll need to buy a power adapter for this one, but after that it's smooth sailing. 4. A clear iPhone 7 case 
Amazon 
A clear iPhone case might seem like a weird commuter-centric choice, unless you've ridden the train twice a day during the winter. 
Instead of reaching into your pocket for your wallet, you can slip your train ticket into the clear case and flash it to the conductor. This saves time and frustration, especially since most of us have our phones in our hands while commuting.
